en: “My dear fellow, I am not quite serious. But I can’t help detesting my relations. I suppose it comes from the fact that none of us can stand other people having the same faults as ourselves. I quite sympathize with the rage of the English democracy against what they call the vices of the upper orders. The masses feel that drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality should be their own special property, and that if any one of us makes an ass of himself, he is poaching on their preserves. When poor Southwark got into the divorce court, their indignation was quite magnificent. And yet I don’t suppose that ten per cent of the proletariat live correctly.”
vi: “Bạn tôi ơi, tôi không nghiêm túc lắm đâu. Nhưng tôi không thể nào thôi căm ghét các mối quan hệ của mình. Tôi cho rằng do thực tế là không ai trong chúng ta có thể chịu đựng được việc người khác có các lỗi lầm giống như của chính chúng ta. Tôi hết sức thông cảm với cơn thịnh nộ của nền dân chủ Anh quốc trước cái mà họ gọi là thói hư tật xấu của giai cấp thượng lưu. Quần chúng cảm thấy rằng tật nghiện rượu, sự đần độn và thói đồi bại nên là đặc tính của riêng họ, và rằng nếu bất cứ ai trong số chúng ta mà lại đi làm trò cười cho thiên hạ thì y đã xâm phạm vào cấm địa của họ. Khi Southwark đáng thương ra tòa li hôn với vợ, sự phẫn nộ của họ thật sự là kỳ diệu. Tuy nhiên tôi không nghĩ là có được mười phần trăm tầng lớp dưới sống đúng mực.”
tr: “Dostum, şaka yapıyorum. Gene de akrabalarımdan nefret etmemek elimde değil. Kendimizdeki kusurları başkalarında görmeye hiçbirimiz dayanamayız da ondan olsa gerek. İngiliz demokrasisinin, yüksek sınıfların kötü yönleri, dedikleri şeylere diş bilemesini ben çok iyi anlıyorum. Halk kitleleri ayyaşlık, aptallık, ahlaksızlık yalnızca onlara özgü olsun istiyor! Bizlerden biri kendini rezil etti mi onların özel mülküne tecavüz edilmiş gibi oluyorlar: Zavallı Southwarkcık kendini boşanma mahkemesinde bulunca halkın gösterdiği öfke harikaydı doğrusu. Oysa proletarya sınıfının onda birinin bile kusursuz yaşam sürdüğünü sanmıyorum.
es: —No hablo del todo en serio. Pero me es imposible no detestar a mi familia. Imagino que se debe a que nadie soporta a las personas que tienen sus mismos defectos. Entiendo perfectamente la indignación de la democracia inglesa ante lo que llama los vicios de las clases altas. Las masas consideran que embriaguez, estupidez e inmoralidad deben ser exclusivo patrimonio suyo, y cuando alguno de nosotros se pone en ridículo nos ven como cazadores furtivos en sus tierras. Cuando el pobre Southwark tuvo que presentarse en el Tribunal de Divorcios, la indignación de las masas fue realmente magnífica. Y, sin embargo, no creo que el diez por ciento del proletariado viva correctamente.
vi_translation: "My friend, I am not very serious. But I cannot help but hate my relationships. I suppose it is because none of us can tolerate others having the same faults as we do. I fully sympathize with the wrath of British democracy against what they call the vices of the upper class. The masses feel that alcoholism, stupidity, and depravity should be their own characteristics, and that if any of us make a fool of ourselves, we have encroached on their territory. When poor Southwark went to court to divorce his wife, their indignation was truly remarkable. However, I do not think that even ten percent of the lower class live properly."
tr_translation: “My friend, I'm joking. Still, I can't help but hate my relatives. It's probably because none of us can stand seeing our own flaws in others. I understand very well the British democracy's grudge against what they call the bad traits of the upper classes. The masses want drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality to be exclusive to them! When one of us disgraces themselves, it's as if their private property has been violated: The public's outrage was truly remarkable when poor little Southwark found himself in the divorce court. Yet, I don't think even one-tenth of the proletariat lives a flawless life.”
es_translation: —I'm not entirely serious. But it is impossible for me not to detest my family. I imagine it is because no one can stand people who have the same flaws as they do. I perfectly understand the indignation of English democracy at what it calls the vices of the upper classes. The masses believe that drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality should be their exclusive domain, and when one of us makes a fool of ourselves, they see us as poachers on their land. When poor Southwark had to appear in the Divorce Court, the indignation of the masses was truly magnificent. And yet, I don't think ten percent of the proletariat lives correctly.

en: The lad started and drew back. He was bareheaded, and the leaves had tossed his rebellious curls and tangled all their gilded threads. There was a look of fear in his eyes, such as people have when they are suddenly awakened. His finely chiselled nostrils quivered, and some hidden nerve shook the scarlet of his lips and left them trembling.
vi: Chàng trai giật mình và lùi lại. Cậu để đầu trần, những chiếc lá hất tung các lọn tóc quăn bất trị và vò rối những sợi tơ mạ vàng của chúng. Có nét sợ hãi trong mắt cậu, như mọi người vẫn bị những khi họ thình lình tỉnh giấc. Đôi lỗ mũi chạm trổ tinh xảo rung lên, một sợi dây thần kinh ẩn mình nào đấy giật nhẹ đôi môi đỏ thắm của cậu và để mặc chúng run rẩy.
tr: Genç adam irkilerek geriledi. Başı açıktı, ağacın yaprakları buklelerini dağıtmış, yaldızlı saç tellerini birbirine karıştırmıştı. Gözlerinde korkulu bir bakış vardı, uykudan birden uyandırılmış kişilerin gözlerindeki gibi. İnce, düzgün çizgili burun delikleri seğiriyordu, gizli bir sinir dudaklarını soldurup titretmiş gibiydi.
es: El muchacho se sobresaltó, apartándose. Llevaba la cabeza descubierta, y las hojas del arbusto le habían despeinado, enredando las hebras doradas. Había miedo en sus ojos, como sucede cuándo se despierta a alguien de repente. Le vibraron las aletas de la nariz y algún nervio escondido agitó el rojo de sus labios, haciéndolos temblar.
vi_translation: The young man was startled and stepped back. He was bareheaded, with leaves tossing his unruly curls and tangling their golden threads. There was a look of fear in his eyes, as people often have when they suddenly wake up. His finely chiseled nostrils quivered, some hidden nerve lightly tugged at his crimson lips, leaving them trembling.
tr_translation: The young man recoiled in shock. His head was bare, the leaves of the tree had tousled his curls and tangled his golden hair strands. There was a fearful look in his eyes, like the eyes of someone suddenly awakened from sleep. His thin, well-defined nostrils were twitching, as if a hidden nerve had drained the color from his lips and made them tremble.
es_translation: The boy started, stepping back. His head was uncovered, and the leaves of the bush had tousled his hair, tangling the golden strands. There was fear in his eyes, as happens when someone is suddenly awakened. His nostrils flared and some hidden nerve twitched the red of his lips, making them tremble.

en: “Always! That is a dreadful word. It makes me shudder when I hear it. Women are so fond of using it. They spoil every romance by trying to make it last for ever. It is a meaningless word, too. The only difference between a caprice and a lifelong passion is that the caprice lasts a little longer.”
vi: “Mãi! Đó là một từ khủng khiếp. Nó khiến tôi rùng mình mỗi khi nghe thấy. Đàn bà rất thích dùng nó. Họ làm hỏng mọi chuyện tình lãng mạn bằng cách cố gắng làm cho chúng kéo dài vĩnh viễn. Nó cũng là một từ vô nghĩa nữa. Sự khác biệt duy nhất giữa sự tùy hứng và niềm đam mê trọn đời là ở chỗ sự tùy hứng kéo dài thêm được ít lâu.”
tr: “Her zaman! Çok çirkin bir deyim bu. Duyar duymaz kanım donar. Kadınlar bayılırlar bunu kullanmaya. Her aşkı, sonsuza dek sürdürmeye çalışarak berbat ederler. Sözcük olarak da anlamsızdır. Bir kaprisle ebedi bir aşk arasındaki tek ayrım kaprisin biraz daha uzun ömürlü olmasıdır.
es: —¡Siempre! Terrible palabra. Hace que me estremezca cuando la oigo. Las mujeres son tan aficionadas a usarla. Echan a perder todas las historias de amor intentando que duren para siempre. Es, además, una palabra sin sentido. La única diferencia entre un capricho y una pasión para toda la vida es que el capricho dura un poco más.
vi_translation: “Forever!” “That is a terrible word. It makes me shudder every time I hear it. Women love to use it. They ruin every romantic affair by trying to make it last forever. It is also a meaningless word. The only difference between a whim and a lifelong passion is that a whim lasts a little longer.”
tr_translation: “Always! It's a very ugly expression. As soon as I hear it, my blood freezes. Women love to use it. They ruin every love by trying to make it last forever. As a word, it is also meaningless. The only difference between a whim and an eternal love is that the whim lasts a little longer.”
es_translation: —Always! Terrible word. It makes me shudder when I hear it. Women are so fond of using it. They ruin all love stories by trying to make them last forever. It is, moreover, a meaningless word. The only difference between a whim and a lifelong passion is that the whim lasts a little longer.

en: Suddenly he stopped and glanced up at the houses. He found that he had passed his aunt’s some distance, and, smiling to himself, turned back. When he entered the somewhat sombre hall, the butler told him that they had gone in to lunch. He gave one of the footmen his hat and stick and passed into the dining-room.
vi: Bỗng dưng y dừng lại và ngó lên các ngôi nhà. Y thấy rằng y đã đi qua nhà dì mình mấy quãng, và, tự cười với mình, quay lại. Lúc y bước vào cái sảnh hơi ảm đạm thì quản gia thưa với y rằng họ đã đi ăn rồi. Y đưa cho một người hầu cầm cái mũ và ba- toong của y, rồi đi vào phòng ăn.
tr: Birden Lord Henry durdu, yandaki evlere baktı. Halasının evini epey geçtiğini görünce kendi kendine gülümseyerek geri döndü. Biraz kasvetli olan hole girdiğinde başuşak ona yemeğin başladığını bildirdi. Lord Henry şapkasıyla bastonunu uşak yamaklarından birine vererek yemek odasına girdi.
es: De repente, lord Henry se detuvo y contempló las casas que lo rodeaban. Se dio cuenta de que había dejado atrás la de su tía y, sonriendo, volvió sobre sus pasos. Cuando entró en el vestíbulo, un tanto sombrío, el mayordomo le hizo saber que los comensales ya se habían sentado a la mesa. Entregó el sombrero y el bastón a uno de los lacayos y pasó al comedor.
vi_translation: Suddenly, he stopped and looked up at the houses. He realized that he had walked past his aunt's house by several blocks, and, smiling to himself, turned back. When he stepped into the somewhat gloomy hall, the butler informed him that they had already gone to eat. He handed his hat and cane to a servant, then went into the dining room.
tr_translation: Suddenly, Lord Henry stopped and looked at the houses beside him. Seeing that he had passed his aunt's house by quite a bit, he turned back with a smile to himself. When he entered the somewhat gloomy hall, the head butler informed him that dinner had started. Lord Henry handed his hat and cane to one of the footmen and entered the dining room.
es_translation: Suddenly, Lord Henry stopped and contemplated the houses that surrounded him. He realized that he had passed his aunt's house and, smiling, retraced his steps. When he entered the somewhat gloomy hall, the butler informed him that the diners had already sat down at the table. He handed his hat and cane to one of the footmen and proceeded to the dining room.

en: “Oh! but I have seen specimens of the inhabitants,” answered the duchess vaguely. “I must confess that most of them are extremely pretty. And they dress well, too. They get all their dresses in Paris. I wish I could afford to do the same.”
vi: “Ồ! Nhưng tôi từng thấy vài thể loại dân đó,” nữ công tước trả lời, rất vô tâm. “Tôi phải thú nhận là phần lớn họ cực kỳ dễ thương. Và họ mặc đồ cũng đẹp nữa. Họ mua mọi món quần áo của họ ở Paris. Tôi ước gì mình có đủ khả năng làm thế.”
tr: Düşes, “Ha! Ama ben oranın yerlilerinden örnekler gördüm,” diye konuştu. “Ne yalan söyleyeyim, çoğunluğu iyice alımlı. İyi de giyiniyorlar. Bütün kılıklarını Paris’ ten alıyorlar. Keşke benim durumum buna elverse!
es: —Sí, sí, pero yo he visto especímenes de sus habitantes —respondió vagamente la duquesa—. He de confesar que la mayoría de las mujeres son extraordinariamente bonitas. Y además visten bien. Compran toda la ropa en París. Me gustaría poder permitírmelo.
vi_translation: “Oh! But I have seen a few of those types of people,” the duchess replied, very carelessly. “I must admit that most of them are extremely charming. And they dress well too. They buy all their clothes in Paris. I wish I could afford to do that.”
tr_translation: The Duchess said, "Ha! But I have seen examples of the natives from there." "To be honest, most of them are quite attractive. They also dress well. They get all their outfits from Paris. I wish my situation allowed for that!"
es_translation: —Yes, yes, but I have seen specimens of its inhabitants —the duchess responded vaguely—. I must confess that most of the women are extraordinarily beautiful. And they also dress well. They buy all their clothes in Paris. I would like to be able to afford it.

en: “Yes,” he continued, “that is one of the great secrets of life. Nowadays most people die of a sort of creeping common sense, and discover when it is too late that the only things one never regrets are one’s mistakes.”
vi: “Vâng,” y nói tiếp, “đó là một trong những bí mật vĩ đại nhất của cuộc sống. Ngày nay phần lớn mọi người chết vì một loại lương tri rón rén, và phát hiện ra lúc đã quá muộn rằng những thứ duy nhất mà người ta chẳng bao giờ hối tiếc chính là các lỗi lầm của mình.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Evet,” diye ekledi. “Yaşamın büyük gizlerinden biridir bu. Şimdilerde çoğu kimse bir tür ilerlemiş sağduyu yüzünden ölüyor. İş işten geçtikten sonra ayırdına varıyorlar ki insanın pişman olmadığı tek şey hatalarıdır.
es: —Sí —continuó el joven lord—; se trata de uno de los grandes secretos de la vida. En la actualidad la mayoría de la gente muere de una indigestión de sentido común y descubre cuando ya es demasiado tarde que lo único que nunca lamentamos son nuestros errores.
vi_translation: “Yes,” he continued, “that is one of the greatest secrets of life. Nowadays most people die of a creeping common sense, and discover too late that the only things one never regrets are one's mistakes.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry added, "Yes." "It is one of the great mysteries of life. Nowadays, most people die of a sort of creeping common sense. They realize too late that the only things one never regrets are one's mistakes."
es_translation: —Yes —continued the young lord—; it is one of the great secrets of life. Nowadays, most people die of an indigestion of common sense and discover when it is already too late that the only things we never regret are our mistakes.

en: “I would sooner come with you; yes, I feel I must come with you. Do let me. And you will promise to talk to me all the time? No one talks so wonderfully as you do.”
vi: “Tôi thích đi cùng anh hơn; vâng, tôi thấy tôi phải đi cùng anh. Hãy cho phép tôi. Và anh sẽ hứa là nói chuyện với tôi mọi lúc chứ? Không ai nói hay như anh.”
tr: “Sizinle gelmeyi yeğlerim. Evet, sizinle olmak geliyor içimden. Kuzum, izin verin de geleyim. Hem de hiç durmadan benimle konuşacağınıza söz verin. Hiç kimse sizin kadar harikulade konuşamıyor.
es: —Prefiero ir con usted; sí, siento que debo ir con usted. Permítamelo. Y prometa hablarme todo el tiempo. Nadie lo hace tan bien.
vi_translation: “I prefer to go with you; yes, I feel I must go with you. Please allow me. And will you promise to talk to me all the time? No one speaks as well as you.”
tr_translation: “I would prefer to come with you. Yes, I feel like being with you. My dear, let me come with you. And promise me that you will talk to me without stopping. No one can talk as wonderfully as you.”
es_translation: —I prefer to go with you; yes, I feel that I must go with you. Allow me. And promise to talk to me all the time. Nobody does it as well as you do.

en: “My dear boy, no woman is a genius. Women are a decorative sex. They never have anything to say, but they say it charmingly. Women represent the triumph of matter over mind, just as men represent the triumph of mind over morals.”
vi: “Cậu bé thân mến của tôi ơi, chẳng có gái nào là thiên tài cả. Gái là giới tính để làm cảnh. Họ chẳng bao giờ có gì để nói, nhưng họ lại nói chuyện rất duyên. Gái đại diện cho chiến thắng của vật chất trước tinh thần, đúng như trai đại diện cho chiến thắng của tinh thần trước luân lý.”
tr: “Sevgili yavrum, hiçbir kadın büyük yetenek olamaz. Kadınlar süs için yaratılmış bir cinstirler. Hiçbir zaman söyleyecek bir şeyleri yoktur, ama pek tatlı söylerler bunu. Kadınlar fiziğin zihin üstündeki yengisini simgelerler, nasıl ki erkekler de zihnin ahlak üstündeki yengisinin simgeleridir.
es: —Mi querido muchacho, ninguna mujer es un genio. Las mujeres son un sexo decorativo. Nunca tienen nada que decir, pero lo dicen encantadoramente. Representan el triunfo de la materia sobre la mente, de la misma manera que los hombres representan el triunfo de la mente sobre la moral.
vi_translation: “My dear boy, there are no girls who are geniuses. Girls are the gender meant for display. They never have anything to say, but they speak very charmingly. Girls represent the triumph of matter over spirit, just as boys represent the triumph of spirit over morality.”
tr_translation: “My dear child, no woman can be a great talent. Women are a gender created for adornment. They never have anything to say, but they say it very sweetly. Women symbolize the triumph of the physical over the mind, just as men symbolize the triumph of the mind over morality.”
es_translation: —My dear boy, no woman is a genius. Women are a decorative sex. They never have anything to say, but they say it charmingly. They represent the triumph of matter over mind, in the same way that men represent the triumph of mind over morals.

en: “Then he asked me if I wrote for any of the newspapers. I told him I never even read them. He seemed terribly disappointed at that, and confided to me that all the dramatic critics were in a conspiracy against him, and that they were every one of them to be bought.”
vi: “Sau đó lão hỏi tôi có phải tôi viết cho tờ báo nào đó không. Tôi bảo lão rằng tôi chưa bao giờ thậm chí là đọc chúng. Lão dường như thất vọng ghê gớm với việc ấy, và tâm sự với tôi rằng mọi nhà phê bình kịch nghệ đang tham gia vào một âm mưu hống lại lão, và rằng họ là cái bọn mà đứa nào cũng bị mua.”
tr: “Sonra bana gazeteci olup olmadığımı sordu. Ben de gazete okumadığımı söyledim. Adam bunu duyunca çok büyük hayal kırıklığına uğradı, besbelli. Bütün tiyatro eleştirmenlerinin ona karşı komplo kurduklarını, hepsinin de hiç ayrımsız satılık olduklarını anlattı bana.
es: —Luego me preguntó si escribía para algún periódico. Le dije que nunca los leía. Pareció terriblemente decepcionado al oírlo, y me confesó que todos los críticos teatrales le eran hostiles y que a todos se los podía comprar.
vi_translation: “Then he asked me if I wrote for any newspaper. I told him that I had never even read them. He seemed terribly disappointed by that, and confided in me that all the theater critics were part of a conspiracy against him, and that they were all bought.”
tr_translation: “Then he asked me if I was a journalist. I told him that I didn't read newspapers. When he heard this, he was very disappointed, obviously. He told me that all theater critics were conspiring against him, and that they were all, without exception, for sale.”
es_translation: —Then he asked me if I wrote for any newspaper. I told him that I never read them. He seemed terribly disappointed to hear that, and he confessed to me that all the theater critics were hostile to him and that they could all be bought.

en: He began to wonder whether we could ever make psychology so absolute a science that each little spring of life would be revealed to us. As it was, we always misunderstood ourselves and rarely understood others. Experience was of no ethical value. It was merely the name men gave to their mistakes. Moralists had, as a rule, regarded it as a mode of warning, had claimed for it a certain ethical efficacy in the formation of character, had praised it as something that taught us what to follow and showed us what to avoid. But there was no motive power in experience. It was as little of an active cause as conscience itself. All that it really demonstrated was that our future would be the same as our past, and that the sin we had done once, and with loathing, we would do many times, and with joy.
vi: Y bắt đầu tự hỏi không biết ta có thể biến tâm lý học thành một môn khoa học thuần túy để mỗi vết nứt nhỏ của đời đều bị lộ ra trước ta hay không. Tuy nhiên ta luôn hiểu lầm về mình và hiếm khi hiểu được người khác. Kinh nghiệm không có giá trị luân thường đạo lý nào cả. Nó chỉ là cái tên mà con người gán cho các lỗi lầm của mình. Các nhà đạo đức học, theo lệ thường, xem nó như một phương thức cảnh báo, đã đòi cho nó một hiệu lực luân lý nhất định trong sự hình thành tính cách, đã tán dương nó như thứ gì đó dạy ta biết điều gì nên theo đuổi và cho ta thấy điều gì nên tránh. Nhưng không có động lực nào trong kinh nghiệm. Nó cũng ít mục đích tích cực như chính lương tâm. Mọi điều mà nó thật sự chứng minh được chỉ là tương lai ta cũng chẳng khác gì quá khứ ta, và cái tội lỗi mà ta từng có lần phạm phải, cùng với nỗi kinh tởm, thì ta vẫn sẽ phạm tiếp nhiều lần nữa, mà với niềm vui.
tr: Lord Henry merak etmeye başlamıştı: Acaba psikolojiyi alabildiğine kesin, mutlak bir bilim dalı haline getirerek en küçük yaşam pınarlarının bile göz önüne serilmesini sağlamak elimizde miydi? Şu durumda kendi kendimizi hep yanlış anlıyor, başkalarını da pek seyrek anlayabiliyorduk. Deneyim denen şey etik yönden bir değer taşımıyordu. İnsanların hatalarına verdikleri bir addan ibaretti. Ahlakçılar genel olarak bunu bir tür uyarı saymışlar, kişiliğin gelişmesinde etik bir yararı olduğunu ileri sürmüşler, neyi izleyip neden kaçınacağımıza ilişkin bir işaret diye övünmüşlerdi. Şu var ki deneyimde itici güç yoktu. Oynadığı etkin rol vicdanın rolü kadar önemsizdi. Ortaya koyduğu tek gerçek, geleceğimizin de geçmişimize eş olacağıydı; bundan önce bir kez, tiksinerek işlediğimiz günahı bundan böyle birçok kez işleyecektik, hem de seve seve.
es: Empezó a preguntarse si alguna vez se conseguiría hacer de la psicología una ciencia tan exacta que fuese capaz de revelarnos hasta el último manantial de la vida. Mientras tanto, siempre nos equivocamos sobre nosotros mismos y raras veces entendemos a los demás. La experiencia carece de valor ético. Es sencillamente el nombre que dan los hombres a sus errores. Por regla general los moralistas la consideran una advertencia, reclaman para ella cierta eficacia ética en la formación del carácter, la alaban como algo que nos enseña qué camino hemos de seguir y qué abismos evitar. Pero la experiencia carece de fuerza determinante. Tiene tan poco de causa activa como la misma conciencia. Lo único que realmente demuestra es que nuestro futuro será igual a nuestro pasado, y que el pecado que hemos cometido una vez, y con amargura, lo repetiremos muchas veces, y con alegría.
vi_translation: Y began to wonder if it was possible to turn psychology into a pure science so that every small crack in life would be exposed before us. However, we always misunderstand ourselves and rarely understand others. Experience has no moral value at all. It is merely the name people give to their mistakes. Ethicists, as usual, see it as a warning method, demand a certain moral efficacy in character formation for it, and praise it as something that teaches us what to pursue and shows us what to avoid. But there is no motivation in experience. It has as little positive purpose as conscience itself. All it truly proves is that our future will be no different from our past, and the sin we once committed with disgust, we will continue to commit many times more, but with joy.
tr_translation: Lord Henry had begun to wonder: Was it within our power to turn psychology into an absolutely precise and definitive science, thereby ensuring that even the smallest springs of life were laid bare? In that case, we were always misunderstanding ourselves and rarely understanding others. What was called experience had no ethical value. It was merely a name people gave to their mistakes. Moralists generally considered it a kind of warning, claimed it had an ethical benefit in the development of personality, and boasted that it was a sign of what to follow and what to avoid. However, there was no driving force in experience. The active role it played was as insignificant as the role of conscience. The only truth it revealed was that our future would be equal to our past; we would commit the sin we once committed with disgust many times in the future, and this time with pleasure.
es_translation: He began to wonder if psychology would ever become such an exact science that it could reveal to us the very last spring of life. Meanwhile, we always make mistakes about ourselves and rarely understand others. Experience lacks ethical value. It is simply the name men give to their errors. Generally, moralists consider it a warning, claim for it some ethical efficacy in character formation, and praise it as something that teaches us which path to follow and which abysses to avoid. But experience lacks determining force. It has as little active cause as conscience itself. The only thing it really proves is that our future will be the same as our past, and that the sin we have committed once, and with bitterness, we will repeat many times, and with joy.

en: “You pain me, my son. I trust you will return from Australia in a position of affluence. I believe there is no society of any kind in the Colonies—nothing that I would call society—so when you have made your fortune, you must come back and assert yourself in London.”
vi: “Con làm mẹ đau đớn, con trai của mẹ. Mẹ tin con sẽ quay về từ Úc với địa vị giàu sang. Mẹ tin là không có tầng lớp thượng lưu bất cứ dạng nào ở các thuộc địa, không có gì mà mẹ có thể gọi là tầng lớp thượng lưu; vậy nên khi con đã phát đạt rồi thì con phải quay về và khẳng định mình ở London.”
tr: “Beni üzüyorsun, oğlum. Ben senin Avustralya’dan paralı pullu, mevki sahibi bir adam olarak döneceğine inanıyorum. Kolonilerde sosyete diye bir şey olduğuna inanmıyorum, yani benim sosyete diyebileceğim herhangi bir şey. Bu yüzden, orada yükünü tuttuktan sonra buraya dönüp Londra’da kendini göstermek zorundasın.
es: —Me duele que digas eso, hijo mío. No pierdo la esperanza de que regreses de Australia después de hacer fortuna. Creo que la buena sociedad no existe en las colonias; al menos, nada de lo que yo considero buena sociedad; de manera que cuando hayas triunfado deberás volver a Londres y convertirte aquí en una persona conocida.
vi_translation: "You cause me pain, my son. I believe you will return from Australia with a wealthy status. I believe there is no upper class of any kind in the colonies, nothing that I can call the upper class; so when you have succeeded, you must come back and establish yourself in London."
tr_translation: "You are upsetting me, my son. I believe that you will return from Australia as a wealthy and reputable man. I do not believe that there is such a thing as society in the colonies, at least not anything I would call society. Therefore, after you have made your fortune there, you must return here and make your mark in London."
es_translation: —It hurts me that you say that, my son. I haven't lost hope that you will return from Australia after making a fortune. I believe that good society does not exist in the colonies; at least, nothing of what I consider good society; so when you have succeeded, you should return to London and become a well-known person here.

en: He hesitated for a moment. “Very well,” he said at last, “but don’t be too long dressing.” She danced out of the door. One could hear her singing as she ran upstairs. Her little feet pattered overhead.
vi: Cậu lưỡng lự một lúc. “Thôi được,” rốt cuộc cậu nói, “nhưng đừng thay đồ quá lâu đấy.” Nàng nhảy chân sáo ra khỏi cửa. Có thể nghe tiếng nàng hát lúc nàng chạy lên gác. Đôi chân nhỏ của nàng gõ lốp cốp trên đầu.
tr: James bir an duraladı. Sonunda, “Peki,” dedi. “Ama giyinip kuşanacağım diye pek oyalanma. Sibyl dans edercesine odadan çıktı. Üst katta şarkı söylediğini duydular. O küçük ayakları tavanda pıtırdıyordu.
es: James vaciló un momento. —De acuerdo —dijo por fin—, pero no tardes demasiado en vestirte. Sibyl dio unos pasos de baile hasta la puerta. Se la oyó cantar mientras subía corriendo las escaleras y luego el ruido de sus pies en el piso superior.
vi_translation: He hesitated for a moment. "Alright," he finally said, "but don't take too long to change." She skipped out of the door. You could hear her singing as she ran upstairs. Her little feet pitter-pattered overhead.
tr_translation: James paused for a moment. Finally, he said, "Alright." "But don't take too long getting dressed up." Sibyl exited the room as if dancing. They heard her singing upstairs. Her little feet were pattering on the ceiling.
es_translation: James hesitated for a moment. —Alright —he finally said—, but don't take too long to get dressed. Sibyl took a few dance steps to the door. She was heard singing as she ran up the stairs and then the sound of her feet on the upper floor.

en: “No,” answered his mother with a placid expression in her face. “He has not yet revealed his real name. I think it is quite romantic of him. He is probably a member of the aristocracy.”
vi: “Chưa,” mẹ cậu trả lời, với vẻ bình thản trên mặt. “Cậu ấy còn chưa để lộ tên thật. Mẹ nghĩ thế cũng khá là lãng mạn về phía cậu ấy. Cậu ấy chắc là một thành viên của tầng lớp quý tộc.”
tr: Annesi yüzünde dingin bir ifadeyle, “Hayır,” dedi. “Henüz adını açıklamış değil. Bence pek romantik bir şey bu. Aristokrasiden biri olsa gerek.
es: —No —respondió la señora Vane con una plácida expresión en el rostro—. No ha revelado aún su verdadero nombre. Y me parece muy romántico. Probablemente se trata de un aristócrata.
vi_translation: “Not yet,” his mother replied, with a calm expression on her face. “He hasn't revealed his real name yet. I think it's quite romantic of him. He must be a member of the nobility.”
tr_translation: With a serene expression on her face, his mother said, "No." "He hasn't revealed his name yet. I think it's quite a romantic thing. He must be someone from the aristocracy."
es_translation: —No —responded Mrs. Vane with a serene expression on her face—. He hasn't revealed his true name yet. And I find it very romantic. He is probably an aristocrat.

en: “Nothing,” he answered. “I suppose one must be serious sometimes. Good-bye, Mother; I will have my dinner at five o’clock. Everything is packed, except my shirts, so you need not trouble.”
vi: “Không có gì,” cậu trả lời. “Em cho là ta thỉnh thoảng cũng nên sống nghiêm túc. Tạm biệt mẹ; con sẽ ăn tối lúc năm giờ. Mọi thứ đã đóng gói xong, ngoài sơ mi của con, nên mẹ không cần phải lo.”
tr: James Vane, “Hiçbir şey,” diye yanıtladı. “İnsan arada bir ciddi olamaz mı? Hoşça kal, anne. Akşam yemeğini saat beşte yiyeceğim. Gömleklerimden başka her şeyi bavuluma koydum, sen hiç zahmet etme.
es: —Nada —respondió su hermano—. Supongo que a veces hay que ponerse serio. Hasta luego, madre; cenaré a las cinco. El equipaje está hecho, a excepción de las camisas, así que no tienes que preocuparte.
vi_translation: “Nothing,” he replied. “I suppose we should live seriously from time to time. Goodbye mother; I will have dinner at five o'clock. Everything is packed, except for my shirt, so you don't need to worry.”
tr_translation: James Vane, "Nothing," he replied. "Can't a person be serious once in a while? Goodbye, mother. I will have dinner at five o'clock. I've packed everything in my suitcase except for my shirts, don't worry about it."
es_translation: —Nothing —replied his brother—. I suppose sometimes you have to get serious. See you later, mother; I will have dinner at five. The luggage is packed, except for the shirts, so you don't have to worry.

en: They went out into the flickering, wind-blown sunlight and strolled down the dreary Euston Road. The passersby glanced in wonder at the sullen heavy youth who, in coarse, ill-fitting clothes, was in the company of such a graceful, refined-looking girl. He was like a common gardener walking with a rose.
vi: Họ đi ra ngoài và vào trong ánh nắng lung linh lộng gió, tản bộ xuống đường Euston ảm đạm. Khách qua đường liếc nhìn đầy vẻ ngạc nhiên vào gã thanh niên rầu rĩ, thô kệch, ăn mặc tồi tàn, xộc xệch, đi cùng một thiếu nữ yêu kiều, nhìn rất tao nhã. Cậu giống như một gã làm vườn tầm thường đang bước đi với một bông hồng.
tr: Rüzgârla savrularak yanıp dönen güneş ışığına çıktılar, sıkıcı Euston Sokağı’ndan aşağı yürümeye başladılar. Kaba saba, biçimsiz giysileriyle böylesine zarif, kibar bir kızın yanında yürüyen bu hantal, somurtkan gence tuhaf tuhaf bakıyorlardı gelip geçenler. Sıradan bir bahçıvanın bir gülle kol kola yürümesi gibiydi bu.
es: Salieron a una luz de reflejos agitados por el viento y empezaron a caminar por la deprimente Euston Road. Los viandantes miraban con asombro al joven corpulento y hosco que, con ropa basta y nada favorecedora, iba acompañado de una joven tan atractiva y de aspecto refinado. Era como un vulgar jardinero paseando con una rosa.
vi_translation: They went outside and into the shimmering, breezy sunlight, strolling down the gloomy Euston Road. Passersby glanced with surprise at the gloomy, coarse, poorly dressed, and disheveled young man walking with a graceful young lady who looked very elegant. He looked like an ordinary gardener walking with a rose.
tr_translation: They stepped into the sunlight that flickered and turned with the wind, and began to walk down the dreary Euston Street. Passersby were giving strange looks to the hulking, sullen young man walking beside such an elegant, polite girl, with his coarse, shapeless clothes. It was like an ordinary gardener walking arm in arm with a rose.
es_translation: They went out into a light with reflections agitated by the wind and began to walk along the depressing Euston Road. The pedestrians looked in astonishment at the burly and sullen young man who, dressed in coarse and unflattering clothes, was accompanied by a young woman so attractive and refined in appearance. It was like a common gardener walking with a rose.

en: They took their seats amidst a crowd of watchers. The tulip-beds across the road flamed like throbbing rings of fire. A white dust—tremulous cloud of orris-root it seemed—hung in the panting air. The brightly coloured parasols danced and dipped like monstrous butterflies.
vi: Họ ngồi giữa đám đông người ngắm cảnh. Các bồn hoa uất kim hương bên kia đường bừng lên như những chiếc nhẫn lửa rộn ràng. Bụi trắng, y như đám mây phấn rễ diên vĩ rung rinh, lơ lửng trong không khí khát khao. Những chiếc dù rực rỡ sắc màu bập bồng như những con bướm khổng lồ.
tr: Kalabalığın içinde yerlerini aldılar. Yolun karşısındaki lale yatakları ateş halkaları gibi yalazlanıyordu. Sıcaktan soluğu kesilmişe benzeyen havaya, süsen tozunu andıran titrek beyaz bir sis çökmüştü. Parlak renkli şemsiyeler dev kelebekler gibi inip kalkıyordu.
es: Se sentaron en medio de una multitud de ociosos. Los macizos de tulipanes al otro lado de la avenida ardían, convertidos en palpitantes anillos de fuego. Un polvo blanco, se diría una trémula nube de polvo de lirios, flotaba en el aire jadeante. Los parasoles de colores brillantes subían y bajaban como mariposas gigantes.
vi_translation: They sat amidst the crowd of people watching the scenery. The tulip flower beds across the street bloomed like lively rings of fire. White dust, like a cloud of iris root powder, swayed and hovered in the yearning air. The brightly colored umbrellas floated like giant butterflies.
tr_translation: They took their places in the crowd. The tulip beds across the road were flickering like rings of fire. A trembling white mist, resembling iris dust, had settled in the air, which seemed to have lost its breath from the heat. Brightly colored umbrellas were bobbing up and down like giant butterflies.
es_translation: They sat in the midst of a crowd of idlers. The tulip beds on the other side of the avenue burned, turned into throbbing rings of fire. A white dust, it seemed like a trembling cloud of lily dust, floated in the panting air. The bright-colored parasols rose and fell like giant butterflies.

en: She heaved a deep sigh. It was a sigh of relief. The terrible moment, the moment that night and day, for weeks and months, she had dreaded, had come at last, and yet she felt no terror. Indeed, in some measure it was a disappointment to her. The vulgar directness of the question called for a direct answer. The situation had not been gradually led up to. It was crude. It reminded her of a bad rehearsal.
vi: Bà thốt ra một tiếng thở sâu. Đó là dấu hiệu nhẹ nhõm. Khoảnh khắc khủng khiếp, cái khoảnh khắc mà hết ngày đến đêm, hết tuần này qua tháng nọ, bà từng khiếp sợ, rốt cuộc cũng đã đến, tuy nhiên bà không thấy sợ. Quả thật là ở mức nào đó thì nó là một sự thất vọng với bà. Sự thẳng thắn thô thiển của câu hỏi yêu cầu một câu trả lời trực tiếp. Tình huống không được dẫn dắt dần dần từng bước. Nó thật sống sượng. Nó nhắc bà nhớ đến một buổi diễn thử tồi tệ.
tr: ms Vane derin bir göğüs geçirdi. Bu bir rahatlama soluğuydu. O müthiş an, haftalar, aylardır her gün her gece ürküntüyle beklemiş olduğu an en sonunda gelip çatmıştı ama kadın korku duymuyordu. Gerçeği söylemek gerekirse bir dereceye kadar hayal kırıklığı olmuştu bu onun için. Sorunun böylece bayağı bir biçimde, doğrudan doğruya sorulması gene kestirme bir yanıt gerektiriyordu. Durum yavaş yavaş gelişmemişti ki! Kabalıktı doğrusu. ms Vane’e kötü giden bir provayı anımsatmıştı.
es: La señora Vane dejó escapar un hondo suspiro, un suspiro de alivio. El terrible momento, el momento que había temido de día y de noche, durante semanas y meses, había llegado al fin, pero no sentía terror. En cierta medida, de hecho, fue más bien una desilusión. Una pregunta tan vulgarmente directa exigía una respuesta igualmente directa. No era una situación a la que se hubiera llegado poco a poco. Era tosca. A la señora Vane le hizo pensar en un ensayo poco satisfactorio.
vi_translation: She let out a deep sigh. It was a sign of relief. The dreadful moment, the moment that she had feared day and night, week after week, month after month, had finally come, yet she did not feel afraid. Indeed, to some extent, it was a disappointment to her. The bluntness of the question demanded a direct answer. The situation was not gradually led step by step. It was really crude. It reminded her of a bad rehearsal.
tr_translation: Ms. Vane took a deep breath. It was a sigh of relief. That tremendous moment, the moment she had been waiting for with dread every day and night for weeks, months, had finally arrived, but the woman was not afraid. To tell the truth, it was somewhat disappointing for her. The question being asked so plainly and directly required a straightforward answer. The situation had not developed gradually! It was indeed rude. It reminded Ms. Vane of a poorly performed rehearsal.
es_translation: Mrs. Vane let out a deep sigh, a sigh of relief. The terrible moment, the moment she had feared day and night, for weeks and months, had finally arrived, but she did not feel terror. To some extent, in fact, it was rather a disappointment. Such a vulgarly direct question demanded an equally direct answer. It was not a situation that had been reached gradually. It was crude. It made Mrs. Vane think of an unsatisfactory rehearsal.

en: She shook her head. “I knew he was not free. We loved each other very much. If he had lived, he would have made provision for us. Don’t speak against him, my son. He was your father, and a gentleman. Indeed, he was highly connected.”
vi: Bà lắc đầu. “Mẹ biết ông ấy vướng bận. Cha mẹ rất yêu nhau. Nếu ông ấy còn sống, có lẽ ông ấy đã chu cấp cho chúng ta. Đứng phê phán ông ấy, con trai của mẹ. Ông ấy là cha con, và là một quý nhân. Quả thực là ông ấy có dòng dõi quyền quý.”
tr: Annesi başını sarstı. “Onun serbest olmadığını biliyordum. Birbirimizi çok seviyorduk. Yaşasaydı bizim geçimimizi sağlayacaktı. Onu kötüleme, evladım. O senin babandı ve bir centilmendi. İnan, çok yüksek bir ailedendi.
es: Su madre negó con la cabeza. —Yo sabía que no estaba libre. Nos queríamos mucho. Si hubiera vivido, habría atendido a nuestras necesidades. No lo condenes, hijo mío. Era tu padre y un caballero. Pertenecía a una excelente familia.
vi_translation: She shook her head. "I know he was preoccupied. Your father and I loved each other very much. If he were still alive, he would probably have provided for us. Do not criticize him, my son. He is your father, and a noble man. Indeed, he comes from a noble lineage."
tr_translation: His mother shook her head. “I knew he wasn't free. We loved each other very much. If he had lived, he would have provided for us. Don't speak ill of him, my child. He was your father and a gentleman. Believe me, he came from a very distinguished family.”
es_translation: His mother shook her head. —I knew he wasn't free. We loved each other very much. If he had lived, he would have attended to our needs. Do not condemn him, my son. He was your father and a gentleman. He belonged to an excellent family.

en: “Yes, we are overcharged for everything nowadays. I should fancy that the real tragedy of the poor is that they can afford nothing but self-denial. Beautiful sins, like beautiful things, are the privilege of the rich.”
vi: “Vâng, ta phải trả cái giá quá đắt cho mọi thứ thời nay. Tôi cho rằng bi kịch thực sự của người nghèo là họ không thể đủ khả năng để làm bất cứ cái gì ngoài sự hy sinh. Các tội lỗi đẹp đẽ, cũng như các thứ đẹp đẽ, là đặc quyền đặc lợi của người giàu.”
tr: “Evet, bugünlerde her şeyimizi aşırı pahalıya satın alıyorum. Bana kalırsa yoksulların gerçek trajedisi şu ki keseleri ancak karınlarını doyurmaya yetiyor. Güzel günahlar da, güzel nesneler gibi, zenginlerin harcıdır.
es: —Sí, en los tiempos que corren se nos cobra excesivamente por todo. Tengo la impresión de que la verdadera tragedia de los pobres es que no pueden permitirse nada excepto renunciar a sí mismos. Los pecados hermosos, como los objetos hermosos, son el privilegio de los ricos.
vi_translation: “Yes, we have to pay too high a price for everything these days. I think the real tragedy of the poor is that they cannot afford to do anything except sacrifice. Beautiful sins, like beautiful things, are the privilege of the rich.”
tr_translation: “Yes, these days I buy everything at an extremely high price. In my opinion, the real tragedy of the poor is that their purses are only enough to fill their stomachs. Beautiful sins, like beautiful objects, are the domain of the rich.”
es_translation: —Yes, in these times we are excessively charged for everything. I have the impression that the true tragedy of the poor is that they cannot afford anything except to give up on themselves. Beautiful sins, like beautiful objects, are the privilege of the rich.

en: “Possibly,” he sighed, “but they invariably want it back in such very small change. That is the worry. Women, as some witty Frenchman once put it, inspire us with the desire to do masterpieces and always prevent us from carrying them out.”
vi: “Cũng có thể,” y thở dài, “nhưng họ lúc nào cũng muốn nó quay lại từng trinh. Đó chính là điều đáng lo. Đàn bà, như người Pháp dí dỏm nào đó có lần nói, truyền cho ta nỗi khát khao tạo ra các kiệt tác, và luôn ngăn ta thực hiện chúng.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Olabilir,” diye içini çekti. “Ne var ki mutlaka kırk para olarak geri isterler. Sıkıntı burada. Esprili bir Fransız’ın dediği gibi, kadınlar bizde başyapıtlar yaratma isteği uyandırırlar, sonra da her keresinde buna engel olurlar.
es: —Es posible -suspiró el otro—,pero inevitablemente lo reclaman en calderilla. Ése es el problema. Las mujeres, como dijo en cierta ocasión un francés con mucho ingenio, despiertan en nosotros el deseo de producir obras maestras, pero luego nos impiden siempre llevarlas a cabo.
vi_translation: “It’s possible,” he sighed, “but they always want it to return to its original state.” “That is the worrying thing.” “Women, as some witty Frenchman once said, inspire in us the desire to create masterpieces, and always prevent us from achieving them.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry sighed, "Maybe." "However, they always want it back as forty pence. That's the problem. As a witty Frenchman once said, women inspire us to create masterpieces, only to prevent us from doing so every time."
es_translation: —It's possible -sighed the other—, but inevitably they demand it in small change. That is the problem. Women, as a very witty Frenchman once said, awaken in us the desire to produce masterpieces, but then they always prevent us from carrying them out.

en: She looked charming as she came out in the moonlight. That could not be denied. But the staginess of her acting was unbearable, and grew worse as she went on. Her gestures became absurdly artificial. She overemphasized everything that she had to say. The beautiful passage—
vi: Nàng trông rất duyên lúc nàng bước ra dưới ánh trăng. Điều ấy không thể phủ nhận được. Nhưng tính sân khấu trong diễn xuất của nàng thì không thể chấp nhận nổi, và tệ đi khi nàng tiếp tục. Các cử chỉ của nàng trở nên giả tạo một cách ngớ ngẩn. Nàng nhấn mạnh quá mức mọi thứ mà nàng phải nói. Đoạn thơ đẹp:
tr: Sibyl ay ışıklı sahneye çıktığı zaman göz okşuyordu. Bu yadsınamazdı. Gelgelelim oyununun yapmacıklığı dayanılır gibi değildi, giderek de kötüleşiyordu. Şimdi jestlerine de gülünç bir yapaylık sinmişti. Söylediği her şeyi aşırı vurguluyordu.
es: De nuevo estaba encantadora cuando reapareció al claro de luna. Eso no se podía negar. Pero lo forzado de su interpretación resultaba insoportable, y fue empeorando con el paso del tiempo. Sus gestos se hicieron absurdamente artificiales. Subrayaba excesivamente todo lo que tenía que decir. El hermoso pasaje:
vi_translation: She looked very charming as she stepped out under the moonlight. That cannot be denied. But the theatricality in her performance was unbearable, and it worsened as she continued. Her gestures became ridiculously artificial. She overemphasized everything she had to say. The beautiful verse:
tr_translation: When Sibyl stepped onto the moonlit stage, she was captivating. This was undeniable. However, the artificiality of her performance was unbearable, and it was getting worse. Now, a ridiculous artificiality had crept into her gestures as well. She was overemphasizing everything she said.
es_translation: She was charming again when she reappeared in the moonlight. That could not be denied. But the forced nature of her performance was unbearable, and it worsened over time. Her gestures became absurdly artificial. She excessively emphasized everything she had to say. The beautiful passage:

en: “I wish she were ill,” he rejoined. “But she seems to me to be simply callous and cold. She has entirely altered. Last night she was a great artist. This evening she is merely a commonplace mediocre actress.”
vi: “Tôi cũng hy vọng cô ấy bị ốm,” cậu đáp lại. “Nhưng tôi thấy dường như cô ấy hoàn toàn chai sạn và lạnh lùng. Cô ấy đã thay đổi hoàn toàn. Đêm gần đây nhất cô ấy còn là một nghệ sỹ vĩ đại. Tối nay cô ấy chỉ là mà một diễn viên tầm thường, hạng xoàng.”
tr: Dorian, “Keşke hasta olsa,” diye yanıtladı. “Bana duygusuz, soğuk gözüktü. Kökten değişmiş. Dün gece büyük bir sanatçıydı. Bu gece sıradan, ortalama bir aktris.
es: —Ojalá estuviera enferma —replicó Dorian Gray—. Pero a mí me ha parecido sencillamente insensible y fría. Ha cambiado por completo. Anoche era una gran artista. Hoy es una actriz vulgar, mediocre.
vi_translation: “I also hope she is ill,” he replied. “But it seems to me that she is completely numb and cold. She has changed completely. Just the other night she was a great artist. Tonight she is just a mediocre, second-rate actress.”
tr_translation: Dorian replied, "I wish she were ill." "She seemed emotionless, cold to me. She has fundamentally changed. Last night, she was a great artist. Tonight, she is an ordinary, average actress."
es_translation: —I wish she were ill —replied Dorian Gray—. But to me, she simply seemed insensitive and cold. She has completely changed. Last night she was a great artist. Today she is a vulgar, mediocre actress.

en: “Horribly!” he answered, gazing at her in amazement. “Horribly! It was dreadful. Are you ill? You have no idea what it was. You have no idea what I suffered.”
vi: “Kinh khủng!” cậu trả lời, nhìn cô sửng sốt — “kinh khủng! Thật hãi hùng. Em ốm à? Em không hình dung được nó thế nào đâu. Em không hình dung được những gì tôi phải chịu đựng đâu.”
tr: Dorian ona şaşkın şaşkın bakarak, “Feci!” dedi. “Feci! Berbattı. Hasta mısın sen? Nasıl kıvrandım, bilemezsin.
es: —¡Horriblemente mal! —respondió él, contemplándola asombrado—. ¡Espantoso! Ha sido terrible. ¿Estás enferma? No puedes hacerte idea de lo que ha sido. No te imaginas cómo he sufrido.
vi_translation: “Terrible!” he replied, looking at her in astonishment — “terrible! Truly horrifying. Are you sick? You can't imagine what it's like. You can't imagine what I have to endure.”
tr_translation: Dorian looked at him in astonishment and said, "Terrible!" "Terrible! It was awful. Are you sick? You can't imagine how I writhed."
es_translation: —Horribly bad! —he responded, looking at her amazed—. Awful! It was terrible. Are you sick? You can't imagine what it was like. You can't imagine how I suffered.

en: She looked at him in wonder and laughed. He made no answer. She came across to him, and with her little fingers stroked his hair. She knelt down and pressed his hands to her lips. He drew them away, and a shudder ran through him.
vi: Nàng ngạc nhiên nhìn cậu, bật cười. Cậu không đáp lại. Nàng đến gần cậu, vuốt ve tóc cậu bằng những ngón tay nhỏ của mình. Nàng quỳ xuống và áp tay hai bàn tay cậu lên môi. Cậu giật chúng ra, một cơn rùng mình chạy xuyên qua cậu.
tr: Kız ona anlamamış gibi bakarak güldü. Dorian karşılık vermedi. Kız geldi, o minik elleriyle onun saçlarını okşadı. Diz çöktü, onun ellerini dudaklarına bastırdı. Dorian ellerini çekti, bedeninde bir ürperti dolaştı.
es: Sibyl lo miró asombrada y se echó a reír. El muchacho no respondió. Ella se acercó, y con una mano le acarició el pelo. A continuación se arrodilló y se apoderó de sus manos, besándoselas. Dorian las retiró, estremecido por un escalofrío.
vi_translation: She looked at him in surprise and laughed. He did not respond. She approached him, gently stroking his hair with her small fingers. She knelt down and pressed his hands to her lips. He pulled them away, a shiver running through him.
tr_translation: The girl laughed, looking at him as if she didn't understand. Dorian did not respond. The girl came over and stroked his hair with her tiny hands. She knelt down and pressed his hands to her lips. Dorian pulled his hands away, a shiver ran through his body.
es_translation: Sibyl looked at him astonished and burst out laughing. The boy did not respond. She approached, and with one hand caressed his hair. Then she knelt down and took his hands, kissing them. Dorian withdrew them, shivering from a chill.

en: Then he leaped up and went to the door. “Yes,” he cried, “you have killed my love. You used to stir my imagination. Now you don’t even stir my curiosity. You simply produce no effect. I loved you because you were marvellous, because you had genius and intellect, because you realized the dreams of great poets and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown it all away. You are shallow and stupid. My God! how mad I was to love you! What a fool I have been! You are nothing to me now. I will never see you again. I will never think of you. I will never mention your name. You don’t know what you were to me, once. Why, once ... Oh, I can’t bear to think of it! I wish I had never laid eyes upon you! You have spoiled the romance of my life. How little you can know of love, if you say it mars your art! Without your art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, magnificent. The world would have worshipped you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.”
vi: Sau đó cậu đứng phắt dậy, đi ra cửa. “Đúng,” cậu kêu lên, “em đã giết chết tình tôi. Em từng khơi gợi trí tưởng tượng của tôi. Bây giờ thậm chí em còn không khơi gợi nổi sự tò mò của tôi. Em đơn giản là không gây được chút ấn tượng nào. Tôi yêu em vì em tuyệt diệu, vì em có thiên tài và trí tuệ, vì em hiện thực hóa được các giấc mộng của những thi nhân vĩ đại và đem được hình hài với chất liệu đến cho những chiếc bóng của nghệ thuật. Em đã vứt bỏ hết rồi. Em rỗng tuếch và đần độn. Chúa ơi! Tôi đã yêu em rồ dại biết bao! Tôi đã khờ dại thế nào! Giờ đây em chẳng còn là gì với tôi nữa. Tôi sẽ không bao giờ gặp lại em. Tôi sẽ không bao giờ nghĩ đến em. Tôi sẽ không bao giờ nhắc đến tên em. Em không biết em từng là thế nào với tôi, trước kia. Sao mà, trước kia… Ôi, tôi không thể chịu được khi nghĩ lại! Tôi ước gì tôi chưa từng để mắt đến em! Em phá hỏng những mơ mộng đời tôi. Sao mà em lại có thể hiểu ít về ái tình như vậy, nếu em nói nó làm hỏng nghệ thuật của em! Không có nghệ thuật thì em chẳng là gì cả. Lẽ ra tôi sẽ làm cho em trở nên nổi tiếng, huy hoàng, lộng lẫy. Lẽ ra thế giới sẽ tôn thờ em, và lẽ ra em sẽ mang tên tôi. Bây giờ em là cái gì? Một cô đào hạng ba với gương mặt xinh xắn.”
tr: Sonra yerinden fırlayarak kapıya yürüdü. “Evet,” diye bağırdı. “Aşkımı öldürdün sen benim. Eskiden hayal gücümü beslerdin. Şimdi merakımı bile uyandıramıyorsun. Zerrece etkilemiyorsun beni. Ben seni sevdimse şahane olduğun için sevdim; üstün yeteneğin, zihinsel gücün vardı, büyük şairlerin hayallerini gerçekleştiriyor, sanatın gölgesine biçim veriyor, somutluk katıyordun. Bunların hepsini fırlatıp attın. Sığ ve aptalsın. Ulu Tanrım! Ne delilikmiş seni sevmek! Ne kadar aptalmışım! Gözümde hiçsin artık. Bir daha asla görmeyeceğim seni, asla düşünmeyeceğim. Adını asla ağzıma almayacağım. Eskiden benim gözümde neydin, bilmiyorsun. Bir de ben... Of, düşünmeye bile dayanamıyorum! Keşke seni hiç görmemiş olsaydım! Hayatımın büyük aşkını mahvettin. Aşkın senin sanatını bozuyor madem, sen aşkı hiç tanımıyorsun demektir! Sanatın olmayınca sen bir hiçsin. Ben seni ünlü, parlak, şahane biri yapacaktım. Dünya senin önünde diz çökecekti, sen de benim adımı taşıyacaktın. Şimdi nesin ki? Güzel yüzlü, üçüncü sınıf bir aktris.
es: Luego se puso en pie de un salto, dirigiéndose hacia la puerta. —Sí —exclamó—; has matado mi amor. Eras un estímulo para mi imaginación. Ahora ni siquiera despiertas mi curiosidad. No tienes ningún efecto sobre mí. Te amaba porque eras maravillosa, porque tenías genio e inteligencia, porque hacías reales los sueños de los grandes poetas y dabas forma y contenido a las sombras del arte. Has tirado todo eso por la ventana. Eres superficial y estúpida. ¡Cielo santo! ¡Qué loco estaba al quererte! ¡Qué imbécil he sido! Ya no significas nada para mí. Nunca volveré a verte. Nunca pensaré en ti. Nunca mencionaré tu nombre. No te das cuenta de lo que representabas para mí. Pensarlo me resulta intolerable. ¡Quisiera no haberte visto nunca! Has destruido la poesía de mi vida. ¡Qué poco sabes del amor si dices que ahoga el arte! Sin el arte no eres nada. Yo te hubiera hecho famosa, espléndida, deslumbrante. El mundo te hubiera adorado, y habrías llevado mi nombre. Pero, ahora, ¿qué eres? Una actriz de tercera categoría con una cara bonita.
vi_translation: Then he stood up abruptly and walked to the door. “Yes,” he cried out, “you have killed my love. You once stirred my imagination. Now you don't even arouse my curiosity. You simply don't make any impression at all. I loved you because you were marvelous, because you had genius and intellect, because you realized the dreams of great poets and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown it all away. You are empty and dull. God! How madly I loved you! How foolish I was! Now you are nothing to me. I will never see you again. I will never think of you again. I will never mention your name again. You don't know what you were to me, before. How, before... Oh, I can't bear to think about it! I wish I had never laid eyes on you! You have ruined the dreams of my life. How can you understand so little about love, if you say it ruins your art! Without art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, magnificent. The world would have worshipped you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.”
tr_translation: Then, she sprang up and walked to the door. “Yes,” she shouted. “You killed my love. You used to nourish my imagination. Now you can't even arouse my curiosity. You don't affect me in the slightest. If I loved you, it was because you were magnificent; you had superior talent, mental strength, you realized the dreams of great poets, gave shape to the shadow of art, and added concreteness. You threw all of that away. You are shallow and stupid. My God! What madness it was to love you! How foolish I was! Now you are nothing in my eyes. I will never see you again, never think of you. I will never utter your name. You don't know what you used to be in my eyes. And I... Oh, I can't even bear to think about it! I wish I had never seen you! You ruined the great love of my life. If love ruins your art, it means you don't know love at all! Without your art, you are nothing. I was going to make you famous, brilliant, magnificent. The world would have knelt before you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A beautiful-faced, third-rate actress.”
es_translation: Then he jumped to his feet, heading towards the door. —Yes —he exclaimed—; you have killed my love. You were a stimulus for my imagination. Now you don't even awaken my curiosity. You have no effect on me. I loved you because you were wonderful, because you had genius and intelligence, because you made the dreams of great poets real and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown all that out the window. You are superficial and stupid. Good heavens! How crazy I was to love you! What a fool I have been! You no longer mean anything to me. I will never see you again. I will never think of you. I will never mention your name. You don't realize what you represented to me. Thinking about it is intolerable to me. I wish I had never seen you! You have destroyed the poetry of my life. How little you know about love if you say it stifles art! Without art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, dazzling. The world would have adored you, and you would have carried my name. But now, what are you? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.

en: He threw himself into a chair and began to think. Suddenly there flashed across his mind what he had said in Basil Hallward’s studio the day the picture had been finished. Yes, he remembered it perfectly. He had uttered a mad wish that he himself might remain young, and the portrait grow old; that his own beauty might be untarnished, and the face on the canvas bear the burden of his passions and his sins; that the painted image might be seared with the lines of suffering and thought, and that he might keep all the delicate bloom and loveliness of his then just conscious boyhood. Surely his wish had not been fulfilled? Such things were impossible. It seemed monstrous even to think of them. And, yet, there was the picture before him, with the touch of cruelty in the mouth.
vi: Cậu buông mình xuống ghế và bắt đầu nghĩ. Đột nhiên trong óc cậu lóe lên những lời cậu nói ở xưởng vẽ của Basil Hallward vào cái hôm bức tranh được hoàn thành. Đúng, cậu nhớ chúng rõ mồn một. Cậu đã thốt lên một mong ước điên cuồng là chính cậu vẫn trẻ, còn bức chân dung già đi; mong vẻ đẹp của cậu không bị phai mờ, còn gương mặt trên tấm toan thì mang gánh nặng đam mê và tội lỗi của cậu; mong hình ảnh được họa lại bị khô héo đi với những nếp nhăn đau khổ nghĩ suy, còn cậu vẫn giữ lại được mọi vẻ tươi nhuận thanh tú và sự đáng yêu của cái tuổi niên thiếu mà hồi ấy vừa mới ý thức được. Có chắc là mong ước của cậu không được thỏa mãn hay không? Những chuyện kiểu này không thể xảy ra. Thậm chí chỉ cần nghĩ về chúng dường như đã quái dị. Tuy nhiên, bức tranh đang trước mặt cậu, với nét tàn nhẫn trên miệng.
tr: Dorian kendini bir koltuğa bırakarak düşünmeye başladı. Birden aklından, portrenin bittiği gün Basil Hallward’ın stüdyosunda söylediği sözler geçti. Evet, açıkça anımsıyordu. Kendisi genç kalsa da portre yaşlansa diye çılgın bir dilekte bulunmuştu; kendi güzelliği hiç pas tutmasa, tutkularıyla günahlarının yükünü tuval üstündeki bu yüz taşısa diye; düşünce ve acı belirten çizgiler bu boyalı yüze kazılsa da kendisi yeni algıladığı şu delikanlılığın nazlı tazeliğini olduğu gibi saklayabilse diye. Ama bu dileği gerçekleşmiş olamazdı, değil mi? Böyle şeyler olanaksızdı. Düşünmesi bile usdışı. Gelgelelim işte resim de gözlerinin önündeydi, dudaklarındaki zalim ifadeyle.
es: Dejándose caer sobre una silla empezó a pensar. De repente, como en un relámpago, se acordó de lo que dijera en el estudio de Basil Hallward el día en que el pintor concluyó el retrato. Sí; lo recordaba perfectamente. Había expresado un deseo insensato: que el retrato envejeciera y que él se conservara joven; que la perfección de sus rasgos permaneciera intacta, y que el rostro del lienzo cargara con el peso de sus pasiones y de sus pecados; que en la imagen pintada aparecieran las arrugas del sufrimiento y de la meditación, pero que él conservara todo el brillo delicado y el atractivo de una adolescencia que acababa de tomar conciencia de sí misma. No era posible que su deseo hubiera sido escuchado. Cosas así no sucedían, eran imposibles. Parecía monstruoso incluso pensar en ello. Y, sin embargo, allí estaba el retrato, con un toque de crueldad en la boca.
vi_translation: He dropped himself into the chair and began to think. Suddenly, the words he had spoken in Basil Hallward's studio on the day the painting was completed flashed through his mind. Yes, he remembered them vividly. He had uttered a wild wish that he himself would remain young while the portrait aged; that his beauty would not fade, while the face on the canvas bore the burden of his passions and sins; that the painted image would wither with the lines of suffering and thought, while he retained all the freshness and charm of youth that he had just become conscious of at that time. Was it certain that his wish had not been fulfilled? Such things could not happen. Even thinking about them seemed bizarre. Yet, the painting was before him, with a cruel expression on its mouth.
tr_translation: Dorian dropped himself into a chair and began to think. Suddenly, the words he had spoken in Basil Hallward's studio on the day the portrait was finished came to his mind. Yes, he remembered them clearly. He had made a wild wish that he might stay young while the portrait grew old; that his own beauty might never fade, and that the burden of his passions and sins might be borne by the face on the canvas; that the lines of thought and suffering might be etched onto that painted face while he kept the delicate freshness of his newly perceived youth. But that wish couldn't have come true, could it? Such things were impossible. Even thinking about it was irrational. Yet there was the picture before his eyes, with that cruel expression on its lips.
es_translation: Letting himself fall onto a chair, he began to think. Suddenly, like a flash of lightning, he remembered what he had said in Basil Hallward's studio the day the painter finished the portrait. Yes; he remembered it perfectly. He had expressed a foolish wish: that the portrait would age and that he would remain young; that the perfection of his features would stay intact, and that the face on the canvas would bear the weight of his passions and his sins; that the painted image would show the wrinkles of suffering and contemplation, but that he would retain all the delicate brilliance and allure of an adolescence that had just become self-aware. It was not possible that his wish had been granted. Things like that didn't happen, they were impossible. It seemed monstrous even to think of it. And yet, there was the portrait, with a touch of cruelty in the mouth.

en: After about ten minutes he got up, and throwing on an elaborate dressing-gown of silk-embroidered cashmere wool, passed into the onyx-paved bathroom. The cool water refreshed him after his long sleep. He seemed to have forgotten all that he had gone through. A dim sense of having taken part in some strange tragedy came to him once or twice, but there was the unreality of a dream about it.
vi: Độ chục phút sau, cậu đứng dậy, khoác vội chiếc áo choàng may tỉ mỉ bằng len ca-sơ-mia thêu lụa, đi vào buồng tắm lát đá mã não. Nước lạnh làm cậu tươi tỉnh lại sau giấc ngủ dài. Cậu dường như đã quên mọi chuyện cậu vừa trải qua. Một cảm giác mơ hồ về việc từng tham gia vào bi kịch lạ lùng nào đó có đến với cậu một đôi lần, nhưng có gì đó phi thực trong giấc mộng về nó.
tr: On dakika kadar sonra Dorian yataktan kalktı, sırtına ipek işlemeli yün kaşmirden gösterişli bir kimono alarak damarlı siyah akik kaplı banyoya geçti. Uyuduğu uzun uykudan sonra serin su tazelik verdi ona. Çektiği sıkıntıların hepsini unutmuş gibiydi. Birkaç kez içine tuhaf bir trajedide rol almış gibi hayal meyal bir duygu düştüyse de bunda bir düşün asılsızlığı vardı.
es: Al cabo de unos diez minutos Dorian se levantó y, echándose por los hombros una lujosa bata de lana de Cachemira con bordados en seda, entró en el cuarto de baño con suelo de ónice. El agua fresca lo despejó después de las muchas horas de sueño. Parecía haber olvidado lo sucedido el día anterior. Una vaga sensación de haber participado en alguna extraña tragedia se le pasó por la cabeza una o dos veces, pero con la irrealidad de un sueño.
vi_translation: About ten minutes later, he stood up, hastily put on a meticulously tailored cashmere coat embroidered with silk, and went into the agate-tiled bathroom. The cold water refreshed him after the long sleep. He seemed to have forgotten everything he had just gone through. A vague feeling of having participated in some strange tragedy came to him a few times, but there was something unreal about the dream of it.
tr_translation: About ten minutes later, Dorian got out of bed, put on a luxurious kimono made of wool cashmere embroidered with silk, and went to the bathroom covered in veined black onyx. After the long sleep he had, the cool water refreshed him. It was as if he had forgotten all the troubles he had endured. Although a vague feeling of having played a role in a strange tragedy crossed his mind a few times, it had the baselessness of a dream.
es_translation: After about ten minutes, Dorian got up and, throwing a luxurious Cashmere wool robe with silk embroidery over his shoulders, entered the bathroom with an onyx floor. The fresh water cleared him after many hours of sleep. He seemed to have forgotten what had happened the day before. A vague sensation of having participated in some strange tragedy crossed his mind once or twice, but with the unreality of a dream.

en: Then he rose from the table, lit a cigarette, and flung himself down on a luxuriously cushioned couch that stood facing the screen. The screen was an old one, of gilt Spanish leather, stamped and wrought with a rather florid Louis-Quatorze pattern. He scanned it curiously, wondering if ever before it had concealed the secret of a man’s life.
vi: Sau đó cậu đứng dậy khỏi bàn, châm thuốc, buông mình xuống chiếc đi-văng lót đệm xa hoa kê đối diện tấm chắn. Tấm chắn là một cổ vật, bằng da Tây Ban Nha mạ vàng, được dập nổi và chế tác với một họa tiết khá cầu kỳ theo phong cách thời Vua Louis XV. Cậu tò mò xem kỹ nó, tự hỏi không biết có khi nào trước đây nó đã từng che đậy bí mật đời ai không.
tr: O zaman Dorian masa başından kalktı, bir sigara yaktı ve kendini paravanın karşısındaki bol yastıklı bir kanepeye bıraktı. Paravan çok eskiydi, yaldızlı İspanyol meşininden yapılmış, biraz gösterişli bir Louis Quatorze baskısıyla süslenmişti. Dorian paravanı merakla süzerek, acaba bundan önce bir insan yaşamının gizine hiç siper oldu mu, diye düşündü.
es: Dorian se alzó entonces de la mesa, encendió un cigarrillo y se dejó caer sobre un diván extraordinariamente cómodo, situado delante del biombo. El biombo era antiguo, de cuero español dorado, estampado con un dibujo Luis XIV demasiado florido. Dorian lo examinó con curiosidad, preguntándose si habría ocultado ya alguna vez el secreto de una vida.
vi_translation: Then he got up from the table, lit a cigarette, and let himself down onto the luxurious cushioned divan opposite the screen. The screen was an antique, made of gold-plated Spanish leather, embossed and crafted with a rather intricate design in the style of King Louis XV. He examined it curiously, wondering if it had ever concealed anyone's secrets before.
tr_translation: Then Dorian got up from the table, lit a cigarette, and threw himself onto a sofa with plenty of cushions opposite the screen. The screen was very old, made of gilded Spanish leather, and adorned with a somewhat ostentatious Louis Quatorze pattern. As Dorian gazed at the screen curiously, he wondered if it had ever shielded the secret of a human life before.
es_translation: Dorian then rose from the table, lit a cigarette, and let himself fall onto an extraordinarily comfortable divan situated in front of the screen. The screen was old, made of gilded Spanish leather, stamped with an overly florid Louis XIV design. Dorian examined it with curiosity, wondering if it had ever hidden the secret of a life.

en: He got up and locked both doors. At least he would be alone when he looked upon the mask of his shame. Then he drew the screen aside and saw himself face to face. It was perfectly true. The portrait had altered.
vi: Cậu đứng dậy và khóa cả hai cửa lại. Chí ít thì cậu cũng sẽ ở một mình khi nhìn vào cái mặt nạ nhục nhã của cậu. Sau đó cậu kéo tấm màn chắn qua bên, và thấy chính mình, mặt đối mặt. Đúng thật rồi: bức tranh đã thay đổi.
tr: Dorian kalktı, kapıların ikisini de kilitledi. Utancının maskesine bakarken yalnız olmalıydı hiç değilse. Dorian paravanı çekti, kendisiyle yüz yüze geldi. Her şey tam anlamıyla gerçekti: Portre değişmişti.
es: Se levantó y cerró las dos puertas con llave. Al menos estaría solo mientras contemplaba la máscara de su vergüenza. Luego apartó el biombo y se vio cara a cara. Era totalmente cierto. El retrato había cambiado.
vi_translation: He stood up and locked both doors. At least he would be alone when he looked at his shameful mask. Then he pulled the curtain aside and saw himself, face to face. It was true: the picture had changed.
tr_translation: Dorian stood up and locked both doors. He had to be alone at least while looking at the mask of his shame. Dorian drew the screen and came face to face with himself. Everything was completely real: The portrait had changed.
es_translation: He got up and locked the two doors. At least he would be alone while he contemplated the mask of his shame. Then he moved the screen and saw himself face to face. It was completely true. The portrait had changed.

en: As he often remembered afterwards, and always with no small wonder, he found himself at first gazing at the portrait with a feeling of almost scientific interest. That such a change should have taken place was incredible to him. And yet it was a fact. Was there some subtle affinity between the chemical atoms that shaped themselves into form and colour on the canvas and the soul that was within him? Could it be that what that soul thought, they realized?—that what it dreamed, they made true? Or was there some other, more terrible reason? He shuddered, and felt afraid, and, going back to the couch, lay there, gazing at the picture in sickened horror.
vi: Như cậu hay nhớ lại sau này, và luôn với chút ngạc nhiên, cậu thấy mình thoạt đầu đã ngắm nhìn bức chân dung với một cảm giác thích thú gần như có tính khoa học. Một sự thay đổi như vậy lại xảy ra được là việc không thể tin nổi với cậu. Tuy nhiên đó là sự thật. Lẽ nào lại có một ái lực tinh vi nào đó giữa các nguyên tử hóa học, những thứ đã tự sắp thành hình và màu trên tấm toan, với linh hồn trong cậu? Liệu có thể nào mà những gì cái linh hồn ấy nghĩ đến thì chúng sẽ hiện thực hóa được? — và những gì nó mơ đến thì chúng sẽ biến thành sự thật? Hoặc còn nguyên nhân nào đó khác, khủng khiếp hơn? Cậu rùng mình, cảm thấy sợ hãi, và, quay lại đi-văng, nằm đó, ngắm bức tranh với nỗi khiếp sợ phát ốm.
tr: Portreyi neredeyse bilimsel bir ilgiyle süzdü. Bu hareketini sonraları şaşırarak anımsayacaktı. Böyle bir değişimin gerçekleşmiş olması usuna sığmıyordu. Gel gör ki değişim gerçekti, vardı, oradaydı. Tuval üzerinde bir araya gelerek rengi ve formu oluşturan kimyasal atomlarla Dorian’ın içindeki ruh arasında gizli bir bağıntı mı vardı yoksa? Bu ruhun düşündüklerini o atomların kavrayabilmesi olası mıydı? Yoksa daha başka, daha müthiş bir neden mi vardı? Genç adam ürperdi, korktu, gene kanepeye gidip uzanarak içini çürüten bir dehşetle gözlerini resme dikti.
es: Como después recordaría con frecuencia, y siempre con notable asombro, se encontró mirando al retrato con un sentimiento que era casi de curiosidad científica. Que aquel cambio hubiera podido producirse le resultaba increíble. Y, sin embargo, era un hecho. ¿Existía alguna sutil afinidad entre los átomos químicos, que se convertían en forma y color sobre el lienzo, y el alma que habitaba en el interior de su cuerpo? ¿Podría ser que lo que el alma pensaba, lo hicieran realidad? ¿Que dieran consistencia a lo que él soñaba? ¿O había alguna otra razón, más terrible? Se estremeció, sintió miedo y, volviendo al diván, se tumbó en él, contemplando el retrato sobrecogido de horror.
vi_translation: As he often recalled later, and always with some surprise, he found himself initially gazing at the portrait with a sense of almost scientific fascination. Such a change occurring was something he found incredible. Yet it was the truth. Could there be some subtle affinity between the chemical atoms, which had arranged themselves into shape and color on the canvas, and his soul? Could it be that what his soul thought of would materialize? — and what it dreamed of would become reality? Or was there some other cause, more terrifying? He shuddered, feeling frightened, and, turning back to the couch, lay there, staring at the painting with a sickening dread.
tr_translation: He scrutinized the portrait with an almost scientific interest. He would later recall this action with surprise. It was beyond his comprehension that such a transformation had taken place. Yet, the transformation was real, it existed, it was there. Was there a hidden connection between the chemical atoms that came together on the canvas to form color and shape and the soul within Dorian? Was it possible for those atoms to grasp the thoughts of this soul? Or was there another, more terrifying reason? The young man shuddered, frightened, and went back to the couch, lying down and fixing his eyes on the painting with a consuming horror.
es_translation: As he would frequently recall later, and always with notable astonishment, he found himself looking at the portrait with a feeling that was almost of scientific curiosity. That such a change could have occurred seemed incredible to him. And yet, it was a fact. Was there some subtle affinity between the chemical atoms, which turned into form and color on the canvas, and the soul that inhabited the interior of his body? Could it be that what the soul thought, they made real? That they gave substance to what he dreamed? Or was there some other, more terrible reason? He shuddered, felt fear, and, returning to the divan, lay down on it, contemplating the portrait overwhelmed with horror.

en: “I am afraid that women appreciate cruelty, downright cruelty, more than anything else. They have wonderfully primitive instincts. We have emancipated them, but they remain slaves looking for their masters, all the same. They love being dominated. I am sure you were splendid. I have never seen you really and absolutely angry, but I can fancy how delightful you looked. And, after all, you said something to me the day before yesterday that seemed to me at the time to be merely fanciful, but that I see now was absolutely true, and it holds the key to everything.”
vi: “Tôi sợ là phụ nữ lại đánh giá cao sự tàn nhẫn, sự tàn nhẫn thẳng thừng, hơn bất cứ thứ gì khác. Họ có những bản năng nguyên thủy kỳ diệu. Ta đã giải phóng họ, nhưng họ vẫn còn là những nô lệ đi tìm chủ nhân của mình, vẫn vậy thôi. Họ thích được thống trị. Tôi chắc chắn là cậu tuyệt vời. Tôi chưa từng thấy cậu thật sự và hoàn toàn tức giận, nhưng tôi có thể hình dung là trông cậu sẽ thú vị thế nào. Và, rốt cuộc thì, hôm kia cậu đã nói với tôi một điều mà lúc ấy với tôi dường như chỉ là tưởng tượng, song bây giờ thì tôi thấy tuyệt đối chính xác, và nó giữ lời giải cho mọi vấn đề.”
tr: “Korkarım ki kadınlar gaddarlığın, hem de katıksız gaddarlığın değerini her şeyden çok bilirler. İçgüdüleri olağanüstü ilkeldir onların. Biz onlara özgürlüklerini verdik, ama onlar gene de efendilerini arayan birer köle olmayı sürdürüyorlar. Hükmedilmeye bayılırlar. Senin şahane davrandığından ben eminim. Seni hiçbir zaman şöyle yüzde yüz öfkeli görmedim, gene de nasıl güzelleştiğini gözümde canlandırabiliyorum. Hem zaten dün değil önceki gün sen bana bir şey söylemiştin. O zaman bana hayal ürünü bir şey gibi gelmişti ama yüzde yüz doğruymuş meğer; şimdi görüyorum. Her şeyin anahtarı da bunda.
es: —Mucho me temo que las mujeres aprecian la crueldad, la crueldad pura y simple, más que ninguna otra cosa. Tienen instintos maravillosamente primitivos. Las hemos emancipado, pero siguen siendo esclavas en busca de dueño. Les encanta que las dominen. Estoy seguro de que estuviste espléndido. No te he visto nunca enfadado de verdad, aunque me imagino el aspecto tan delicioso que tenías. Y, después de todo, anteayer me dijiste algo que me pareció entonces puramente caprichoso, pero que ahora considero absolutamente cierto y que encierra la clave de todo lo sucedido.
vi_translation: “I am afraid that women tend to value cruelty, blatant cruelty, more than anything else. They have marvelous primal instincts. We have liberated them, but they are still slaves searching for their masters, just the same. They like to be dominated. I am sure you are wonderful. I have never seen you truly and completely angry, but I can imagine how interesting you would look. And, after all, the other day you told me something that at the time seemed like mere imagination to me, but now I see it as absolutely accurate, and it holds the solution to all problems.”
tr_translation: “I'm afraid that women know the value of cruelty, pure cruelty, more than anything else. Their instincts are extraordinarily primitive. We gave them their freedom, but they still continue to be slaves searching for their masters. They love to be ruled. I'm sure you behaved wonderfully.
